user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_ResetState:
```c
void UT_ResetState(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey)
{
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr;
    int32                i;

    StubPtr = UT_StubTable;
    for (i = 0; i < UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS; ++i)
    {
        if (FuncKey == 0 || StubPtr->FuncKey == FuncKey)
        {
            UT_ClearStubEntry(StubPtr);
        }
        ++StubPtr;
    }
    if (FuncKey == 0)
    {
        UT_MaxStubSearchLen = 0;
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UT_ResetState:
#define UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS 200
...
static UT_StubTableEntry_t UT_StubTable[UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS] = {{0}}
...
typedef struct
{
    UT_EntryType_t EntryType;
    uint32         ModeFlags;
    UT_EntryKey_t  FuncKey;
    UT_EntryData_t Data;
} UT_StubTableEntry_t
...
typedef cpuaddr UT_EntryKey_t
...
static uint32              UT_MaxStubSearchLen             = 0
...
static void UT_ClearStubEntry(UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr)
{
    /* Be sure to call free() on any malloc'ed buffers before clearing */
    if ((StubPtr->EntryType == UT_ENTRYTYPE_DATA_BUFFER || StubPtr->EntryType == UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETURN_BUFFER) &&
        StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr != NULL && (StubPtr->ModeFlags & UT_MODEFLAG_ALLOC_BUF) != 0)
    {
        free(StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr);
    }
    memset(StubPtr, 0, sizeof(*StubPtr));
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I selected conditional blocks and the memory-clear operation as items to investigate for potential unreachable code. The for-loop and its inner conditional are the primary control-flow constructs in UT_ResetState and could hide branches that are never taken depending on how FuncKey and the table are used elsewhere. The post-loop conditional that resets UT_MaxStubSearchLen is a distinct branch that might be never reached depending on callers. In UT_ClearStubEntry the conditional free and the subsequent memset are the locations where control flow differs; the free call guards resource release and the memset always follows, so both should be checked for possible dead branches or redundant/unreachable sequences.

Other fragments are not included because they do not present control-flow branches or compile-time constant conditions that would create unreachable code: variable declarations (StubPtr, i), the assignment StubPtr = UT_StubTable, the ++StubPtr increment, the UT_ClearStubEntry function signature and comment, the static declarations (UT_StubTable, UT_MaxStubSearchLen) and the typedefs/constants shown. Those are straightforward data/definition elements or simple operations and, on their own, cannot produce unreachable code under MISRA Rule 2.1; any unreachable-code concern in those areas would manifest through the conditional fragments already listed above.
